I had dinner with J. Allen Hynek, then the former scientific advisor for Operation Blue Book, in 1974. While he had some hair-raising stories to tell, his public evaluation of UFO phenomena was that there are aerial events we cannot explain, that are beyond our capabilities. But, whether or not these are of extraterrestrial origin is not a conclusion he was willing to make. 
Nearly 50 years later, it sounds like the US military has come to about the same conclusion. Not much progress on this question since Blue Book.

In 2007, I saw one of these objects while on patrol as a police officer for a large city. A colonel in the US Air-force, had stopped his vehicle in front of me got out and watched this object with me. For about 30 seconds we watched it jump around the sky right above a CIA facility before it shot straight up and out of view in a matter of seconds. While watching this object, I was about to radio in to dispatch over what I was seeing, when this colonel advised me to re-think that course of action telling me that in his position in the Air Force he had seen hundreds of these objects over the year‚Äôs, and me putting a call out on the air over what I was witnessing would do nothing but get my name on a list that I probably wouldn‚Äôt want to be on. I thought this through for a second and decided he was probably right. So we enjoyed the show the colonel wished me a goodnight and off we went in different directions. Only thing that I wished happened was that I wished smartphones would have been around then, this object was only about 50 feet above the roof of this two story building it was above, as close as I was to this object it would have made for highly detailed photos and video of it.

Let's face it, something unusual is happening in our skies and oceans. Is it a threat? We don't know, but we should not ignore it. UAPs (ie. the new name for UFOs) have been seen and reported for many years, even in antiquity, but military and commercial pilots who reported such encounters faced the end of their careers. Even civilians who reported such encounters were scoffed at and ridiculed. Now, even military pilots are encouraged to report such incidents, so the stigma of reporting them is being removed. Thus, we're likely to see more reports in the future.
